clinical_study.brief_title: The Effect of Active Choice on Nurse Visit Participation
clinical_study.official_title: The Effect of Time-Slot Scheduling and Active Choice on Biometric Screening and Nurse Visit Participation

lead_sponsor.agency: National Bureau of Economic Research, Inc.

clinical_study.source: National Bureau of Economic Research, Inc.

brief_summary.textblock: The goal of this project is to see if behavioral nudges will increase an individual's likelihood of participating in a nurse visit. The behavioral nudges under consideration are encouraging subjects to make an active choice and sending reminders.

detailed_description.textblock: The employees in our sample will schedule their nurse visit time slot via e-mail and a health service provider website. Much as is the case in the current system, the control group will be informed via e-mail of the window of dates during which they can take part in the on-site screening and given instructions for scheduling an appointment. The treatment group, the active choice only arm, will be given the same information as the control group, but they will also be asked to make an appointment immediately, defer the scheduling decision, or decline to receive a screening. The treatment group will also receive email reminders one week before their appointment.

primary_outcome.time_frame: This will be measured after all of the nurse visit windows have been closed, by 4/30/11
primary_outcome.description: We will measure whether or not subjects scheduled and participated in a nurse visit. We will compare the number of subjects who participated in the nurse visits by treatment arms.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Harrah's employee
- Registered e-mail address with Harrah's
- Part of Harrah's Choosing Wellness Program
Exclusion Criteria:
- Under 18
- Already participated in a nurse visit
